mechanoreception.notes: As sea cucumbers, Caudinidae likely possess mechanoreceptors distributed across their body surface to detect vibrations and pressure changes in the surrounding water and substrate. This is important for navigation, predator avoidance, and detecting suitable feeding locations.

chemoreception.notes: Sea cucumbers use chemoreceptors to detect chemical cues in the water and sediment for food detection, mate finding, and habitat selection. Tentacles are likely involved in chemoreception.

photoreception.notes: The presence or absence of photoreceptors in Caudinidae is unknown. Some sea cucumbers have rudimentary light-sensing abilities, but this may not be present in this family.
